In addition, the standard of factual evidence required to prove state involvement can likewise pose significant challenges. For example, in the Oil Platforms case between Iran and the United States – which arose during the 1980–88 Iran-Iraq War – the International Court of Justice ruled in 2003 that the United States had not provided sufficient evidence to prove that Iran was responsible for a 1987 missile attack on a US-flagged tanker, the Sea Isle City.³⁹ The evidence put forward by the United States included satellite imagery of missile sites, expert reports as well as eyewitness testimonies. The standard of evidence required in this case proved to be demanding, although it involved the use of traditional physical force, which often leaves behind a trail of evidence (such as missile sites and other staging grounds, troop movements, or records of the supply of munitions and materiel). In contrast, investigators of cyber-attacks have access only to intangible traces to prove an actor's culpability. Moreover, if the attacks are not conducted by government organs but by individuals or groups directed by a state, the victim state will have to demonstrate that the accused state had 'effective control' in order to impute responsibility to it.
These high standards incorporated in the legal framework that governs state attribution, coupled with the plausible deniability and veil of anonymity afforded by cyber-attacks, create an international legal landscape of attribution highly unsatisfactory to most policy-makers.
The challenge of attribution in relation to cyber-attack has led Matthew Hoisington, for instance, to suggest
that policy-makers should significantly lower the standards of legal attribution, particularly in the case of attacks prompting a response in self-defence. Accordingly, if an attack targets critical national infrastructure, 'a state could respond in presumptively good-faith self-defense without first attributing or characterizing the attack to the level of specificity required under the traditional formulation'.⁴⁰ However, such calls are misplaced. The veil of anonymity and deniability inherent to cyber-attacks is exactly the reason why standards of attribution should remain high, so as to avoid innocent states being accused of conducting cyber-attacks – and being the potential victim of misplaced retaliation. Third parties could also exploit longstanding tensions between states in order to escalate conflict situations.
In light of the arguably unsatisfactory legal framework of attribution, the popularity of sophistication as a criterion in attributing attacks to a state appears understandable. Yet, as has been shown, attribution in legal terms is assessed based on varying degrees of state involvement. According to the principles mentioned above, a victim state would need to ascertain whether an attack originated from a state organ or whether the state in question was in 'effective control' of the entity conducting the attack. The criterion of sophistication cannot replace these guiding principles of the legal assessment of attribution. Sophistication can only serve as an element of evidence within this framework.
## Conclusion
There is no common understanding of the term 'sophistication' as it is used by prominent political figures or by technical
experts in the cyber-security debate. By looking at different case studies, this article has identified several technical and political elements that characterise sophistication in each individual context. The lack of clarity and consistency in the use of the term hinders an informed discussion about the significance of sophistication as a criterion for assessing the likelihood of state sponsorship.
Further, counter-examples have shown that sophistication alone cannot serve as a conclusive determinant in this regard. Sophistication does not necessarily imply state sponsorship — and vice versa. Moreover, the determination of state sponsorship or responsibility in international legal terms follows a different set of criteria based on varying degrees of state involvement. In this framework, sophistication can play only a limited role. It can serve to strengthen or weaken evidence brought forward, but will never constitute a legal criterion in itself. It is therefore important to caution against the significance of sophistication as a seemingly appealing criterion for attribution.
